questions.text: A patient was started on ATT and ART together, Symptoms worsened after 2 months. What can be the cause? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immune reconstitution syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

In patients with both TB and HIV, ATT should be started first. After the patient starts tolerating ATT (approximately 2 weeks), ART should be initiated. This approach is important because if ART is started, it improves immunity which can lead to increased inflammatory response against TB antigens present in various organs. This excessive inflammatory response is called Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS). 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Drug-drug interaction: While interactions can occur between ATT and ART drugs (especially between rifampicin and protease inhibitors), this would manifest differently and not typically cause worsening of symptoms after 2 months of therapy.

 

Option C. Anti-tubercular drug resistance: Anti-tubercular Drug resistance would present as failure to improve rather than initial improvement followed by worsening. Additionally, drug resistance typically develops over a longer period.

 

Option D. Anti-HIV drug resistance: HIV drug resistance typically presents with virological failure rather than worsening of TB symptoms. Additionally, 2 months is too early for HIV drug resistance to develop.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 In patients with both TB and HIV, worsening of symptoms after starting ART is most likely due to IRIS (Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome), which occurs due to improved immunity leading to increased inflammatory response against TB antigens.

 

HIV with TB

 

  • Start ATT first
  • After 2 weeks, start ART

questions.text: A child presents with a fever and a rash. Urine examination showed cells with owl's eye appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

 

Owl's eye appearance on urinary examination is typically seen in Cytomegalovirus.

 

CMV, Human Herpes Virus 5, Largest virus in Herpesviridae family

 

 

 

Other options are not associated with Owl’s eye appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "owl's eye" appearance of cells in the urine is a diagnostic clue for Cytomegalovirus infection, especially relevant for diagnosing congenital CMV infections in neonates or severe infections in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant was brought with complaints of jerking movement of limbs towards the body. On examination, there is a regression of developmental milestones. Electroencephalogram shows hypsarrhythmia. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)

 

The clinical presentation and EEG findings are consistent with infantile spasms, which is seen in WEST Syndrome. The drug of choice for treating infantile spasms in WEST syndrome is adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).

 

Drug of choice of baby with infantile spasms in tuberous sclerosis is vigabtrin.

 

Infantile spasms typically present as clusters of sudden, brief, symmetric, and often flexor or extensor jerks of the limbs or trunk. The spasms are usually associated with regression of developmental milestones, including loss of acquired skills such as smiling, babbling, or sitting up. Hypsarrhythmia, which is a chaotic and disorganized pattern of high-amplitude, asynchronous spikes and slow waves on EEG, is a characteristic finding in infantile spasms.

 

ACTH is the most effective medication for the treatment of infantile spasms. It is believed to work by decreasing the inflammation and abnormal electrical activity in the brain that is thought to be responsible for the spasms. ACTH is typically administered as a daily injection, usually for a duration of several weeks. The response to treatment is usually monitored with serial EEGs, which should show improvement in the hypsarrhythmia pattern.

 

West syndrome is severe generalized epilepsy that begins between the ages of 2 and 12 months. It is characterized by a triad of:

 

  1. Infantile epileptic spasms
  2. Developmental regression
  3. Hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalogram (EEG)

 

Hypsarrhythmia refers to a high voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenytoin: Phenytoin is the second line of drug of choice in neonatal seizures but is not typically used for treating infantile spasms associated with West Syndrome.

 

Option C. Levetiracetam: Levetiracetam is an antiepileptic medication but is not the first-line treatment for West Syndrome.

 

Option D. Phenobarbitone: Phenobarbitone is the first line of drug of choice in neonatal seizures but is not the preferred treatment for infantile spasms in West Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice for treating infantile spasms in West Syndrome.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female, on treatment for diabetes for the last 10 years, has experienced three episodes of candidal vulvovaginitis in the last two months. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Canagliflozin

 

Canagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor, a class of drugs used to treat type 2 diabetes. One of the well-known side effects of SGLT2 inhibitors is an increased risk of fungal infections, particularly candidal infections of the genital tract. This is because SGLT2 inhibitors increase the amount of glucose excreted in the urine, creating an environment conducive to fungal growth. Therefore, in patients with a history of recurrent candidal infections, such as the 60-year-old female in this case, SGLT2 inhibitors like canagliflozin should be avoided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metformin: The most common side effect of metformin is gastrointestinal upset, particularly diarrhea. It does not increase the risk of fungal infections.

 

Option C. Glipizide: This sulfonylurea drug primarily causes hypoglycemia as a side effect. It does not have a significant association with increased risk of fungal infections.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone: This drug can cause weight gain due to fluid retention but does not increase the risk of fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a history of recurrent candidal infections, SGLT2 inhibitors, such as canagliflozin, should be avoided due to their association with increased risk of genital fungal infections.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male was on metronidazole therapy for a bacterial infection. He attended a party and consumed alcohol. Shortly after, he developed symptoms including intense facial flushing, severe nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, palpitations, and hypotension. What is the likely cause? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Drug interaction

 

The patient’s symptoms are indicative of a disulfiram-like reaction, which occurs when alcohol is consumed while taking certain medications, including metronidazole. Metronidazole inhibits the enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to the accumulation of acetaldehyde when alcohol is consumed. This results in symptoms such as facial flushing, nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, palpitations, and hypotension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metronidazole overdose: Metronidazole overdose would typically present with neurological symptoms such as seizures, neuropathy, and encephalopathy, rather than the acute symptoms seen here, which are triggered by alcohol consumption.

 

Option B. Methanol poisoning: Methanol poisoning presents with symptoms such as headache, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, visual disturbances, and in severe cases, metabolic acidosis. The context of alcohol consumption and the specific symptoms make methanol poisoning unlikely in this scenario.

 

Option D. Alcohol withdrawal: Alcohol withdrawal typically presents with symptoms such as tremors, agitation, anxiety, hallucinations, and seizures. It does not present with the acute flushing and gastrointestinal symptoms seen in this case, which are more consistent with a disulfiram-like reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Disulfiram-like reaction by "CGMP" (mnemonic)

 

C – Cefoperazone

 

G – Griseofulvin

 

M – Metronidazole

 

P – Procarbazine

 

Additionally, sometimes can be caused by Isoniazid and chlorpropamide.

 

This reaction typically includes symptoms such as flushing, headache, nausea, vomiting, and palpitations when alcohol is consumed.

questions.text: Following is the x-ray of an 18-year-old boy who complains of fever, pain in the lower limb, local rise of temperature, and tenderness in the area shown. On investigation, he has increased ESR. What can be the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ewing's sarcoma

 

  • This case presents a teenager (18-year-old) with symptoms of fever, pain, local rise in temperature, and tenderness in the lower limb, along with increased ESR are suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma.
  • Radiological features:
    • The first image shows a layered periosteal reaction (onion-skin appearance), which is characteristic of Ewing's sarcoma.
    • The second and third images show a permeative pattern of bone destruction with a soft tissue mass, another hallmark of Ewing's sarcoma.
  • Ewing's sarcoma typically affects children and adolescents (common in ages 10–20).
  • Symptoms include localized pain, swelling, fever, and elevated ESR, often mimicking infection like osteomyelitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Germ cell tumor: Germ cell tumors typically arise in the reproductive organs (testes or ovaries) or occasionally outside these locations (extragonadal). It is not typically a primary bone tumor and doesn't fit the radiographic pattern.

 

Option B. Osteomyelitis: Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone and can cause fever, pain, and elevated ESR, mimicking the symptoms of this case. However, osteomyelitis is more likely to show a solid periosteal reaction or sequestra on x-ray. Osteomyelitis may look similar clinically but rarely shows onion-skin periosteal reaction.

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is another malignant bone tumor that commonly presents with a sunburst appearance and Codman’s triangle on x-ray. However, osteosarcoma typically arises in the metaphysis (the wide part at the ends of bones), particularly in the distal femur or proximal tibia, rather than the diaphysis. It usually presents with pain and swelling but not systemic signs like fever and high ESR to this extent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ewing’s sarcoma typically presents in the diaphysis of long bones in children and adolescents, with a onion skin periosteal reaction seen on x-ray.

questions.text: The formula UV/P represents which one of the following renal functions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clearance

 

The formula UV/P is used to calculate the clearance of a substance in the kidneys. In this formula:

 

  • U stands for the Urinary concentration of the substance.
  • V stands for the Urinary volume or urinary flow rate.
  • P stands for the Plasma concentration of the substance.

 

Clearance refers to the volume of plasma from which a substance is completely removed by the kidneys per unit time. The UV/P formula is applied to determine how effectively the kidneys are clearing a particular substance from the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Filtration Fraction: This is calculated as the Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) divided by the Renal Plasma Flow (RPF).

 

Option B. Tubular secretion: This process involves the transfer of substances from the blood into the tubular fluid.

 

Option C. Tubular reabsorption: This process involves the movement of substances from the tubular fluid back into the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The formula UV/P is used to calculate the clearance of a substance by the kidneys, which reflects how efficiently the kidneys are filtering the blood.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Pancoast tumor? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exophthalmos

 

Pancoast tumor is a tumor of the lung apex that involves compression of the sympathetic chain (particularly the stellate ganglion), causing a constellation of symptoms known as Horner's syndrome. 

 

This syndrome includes;

 

  • Miosis (Pupillary Constriction)
  • Anhidrosis (Decreased Sweating)
  • Ptosis (Drooping of The Upper Eyelid)
  • Enophthalmos (Sunken Eye)

 

Exophthalmos, which is the protrusion of the eyeball, is not a feature of Pancoast tumor or Horner's syndrome. 

 

Educational Objective: 


Pancoast tumor causes Horner's syndrome, which includes miosis, anhidrosis, ptosis, and enophthalmos (MAPE). Exophthalmos is not a feature of Pancoast tumor

questions.text: A young child complained to his parents that he was touched inappropriately by a neighbor.  On examination by a doctor in the OPD, he complained of pain when touched in the perianal area. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow rhombic crystals of spermine pirate. What is the test done? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barberio test

 

As the crystals are seen under the microscope, this indicates that it is a microchemical test.

 

Microchemical tests for Semen: Florence and Barberio test (Both are presumptive tests)

 

Microchemical tests for Blood: Teichmann’s and Takayama test (Both are confirmatory tests)

 

Barberio’s test

 

  • Reagent: Picric Acid
  • Component of semen detected: Spermine (secreted from prostate gland)
  • Shape of crystals: Yellow needle shaped crystals of spermine picrate.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Florence test

 

  • Reagent: KI + I2 + H2O
  • Component of semen detected: Coline (secreted from seminal vesicles)
  • Shape of crystals: Dark Brown rhombic crystals of choline iodide (resemble hemin but larger than hemin crystals)

 

 

Option C. Hemochromogen (Takayama) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaOH + pyridine + glucose
  • Pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen (reduced alkaline hematin)

 

 

Option D. Hemin (Teichmann’s) test:

 

  • Reagent: NaCl + acetic acid
  • Brownish-black rhombic crystals of hematin chloride
  • Negative in old stains or washed or treated with chemicals

 

 

Educational Objective

 

The Barberio test detects the presence of spermine from semen by forming yellow needle-shaped crystals of spermine picrate, making it the correct test for the described scenario.

questions.text: A 4-year-old patient presented with a rectal mass 2.5 cm by 3 cm. On biopsy it had the presence of colonic mucosa with multiple dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells.  Which of the following is a likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hamartoma

 

The clinical history of a rectal mass on biopsy having the colonic mucosa with multiple dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells is suggestive of a juvenile polyp. This polyp is an example of a hamartomatous polyp.     

 

Hamartoma:

 

  • Definition: A hamartoma is a benign, focal malformation that resembles a neoplasm but grows at the same rate as the surrounding tissues. It is composed of an abnormal mixture of tissue elements that are normally found at that site.
  • Juvenile Polyp: A type of hamartomatous polyp commonly found in children. It is characterized by the presence of dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells, as described in the biopsy findings.
  • Clinical Presentation: Typically presents as a solitary rectal polyp in young children, often causing painless rectal bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Choristoma: A benign growth of normal tissue in an abnormal location, not consistent with the described biopsy findings.

 

Option C. Adenoma: A benign neoplasm of glandular tissue, typically presenting with dysplastic changes, not the dilated glands with mucin and inflammatory cells.

 

Option D. Adenocarcinoma: A malignant tumor of glandular origin, which would show invasive growth and cellular atypia, not consistent with the benign nature of the findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A rectal mass in a young child with biopsy findings of colonic mucosa and multiple dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory cells is indicative of a juvenile polyp, which is a type of hamartomatous polyp.

choices.text: Gradual prolongation of PR interval followed by a non-conducted P wave
Prolonged PR interval, and each P wave is followed by a QRS complex
Normal PR interval followed by a non-conducted P wave

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding first-degree AV block? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prolonged PR interval, and each P wave is followed by a QRS complex

 

Explanation:

 

First-degree AV block is characterized by prolongation of the PR interval (>0.2 seconds or >200 milliseconds) with each P wave being followed by a QRS complex. This represents a delay in conduction through the AV node, but every atrial impulse still successfully conducts to the ventricles. On ECG, this appears as more than five small boxes between the P wave and QRS complex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gradual prolongation of PR interval followed by a non-conducted P wave: Incorrect

 

  • Describes Mobitz
  • type I (Wenckebach) second-degree AV block, where PR lengthens progressively until a P wave fails to conduct

 

Option C. Presence of atrioventricular dissociation: Incorrect

 

  • Seen in third-degree (complete) heart block, where the atria and ventricles beat independently
  • P waves and QRS complexes have no relation to each other

 

Option D. Normal PR interval followed by a non-conducted P wave: Incorrect

 

  • Describes Mobitz type II second-degree AV block, where PR remains constant but occasional P waves fail to conduct

 

Educational Objective:

 

First-degree AV block is characterized by a prolonged PR interval (>0.2 seconds) with 1:1 conduction, where each P wave is followed by a QRS complex.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a known history of DM and HTN on regular medications presents with a history of progressively worsening dyspnea on exertion. On examination, there is elevated JVP, positive hepatojugular reflux, crackles at the lung bases, hepatomegaly, ascites, and pedal oedema. What is your provisional diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Heart failure

 

The patient's symptoms and clinical findings are indicative of congestive heart failure (CHF), specifically biventricular failure. The elevated JVP, positive hepatojugular reflux, hepatomegaly, ascites, and pedal edema are typical signs of right heart failure, which suggests poor venous return management by the heart. Additionally, the presence of crackles at the lung bases points to left ventricular failure, which often presents with pulmonary congestion due to backflow of blood into the pulmonary circulation. This combination points to heart failure involving both the left and right sides of the heart (biventricular failure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: While this condition can cause symptoms of heart failure, the presentation would typically include other specific signs such as a systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border and possibly signs of dynamic outflow obstruction, which are not specifically mentioned here.

 

Option C. Mitral regurgitation: Mitral regurgitation could present with symptoms similar to heart failure; however, a hallmark sign would be a pan-systolic murmur heard best at the apex and radiating to the axilla, which isn't mentioned. The systemic signs such as hepatomegaly and ascites are less commonly associated with isolated mitral regurgitation unless it has led to significant heart failure.

 

Option D. Portal hypertension: This condition would explain hepatomegaly and ascites but would not typically include pulmonary symptoms like crackles at the lung bases or findings like elevated JVP and positive hepatojugular reflux without concurrent heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The constellation of symptoms such as elevated JVP, systemic edema (hepatomegaly, ascites, pedal edema), and pulmonary findings (crackles at the lung bases) strongly suggests heart failure, likely due to the patient's known history of hypertension and diabetes contributing to chronic cardiac stress and dysfunction.

 

Reference - Harrison/Clinical Cardiology/Chap 239

questions.text: Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to have?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

After complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Normal gastric secretions contain a glycoprotein called intrinsic factor, secreted by the same parietal cells that secrete hydrochloric acid. Intrinsic factor must be present for adequate absorption of vitamin B12 from the ileum. That is, intrinsic factor combines with vitamin B12 in the stomach and protects it from being digested and destroyed as it passes into the small intestine. Then, when the intrinsic factor–vitamin B12 complex reaches the terminal ileum, the intrinsic factor binds with receptors on the ileal epithelial surface. This in turn makes it possible for the vitamin B12 to be absorbed

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folic acid deficiency: Incorrect as the primary site for folate absorption is the jejunum. While partial jejunal resection could impact folate absorption, the redundancy in folate absorption along the small intestine generally compensates unless the resection is extensive.

 

Option C. Gastric ulcer: Incorrect because gastric ulcers are typically related to factors affecting the stomach lining, such as Helicobacter pylori infection or NSAID use, and are not directly caused by resections of the ileum or jejunum.

 

Option D. Constipation: Incorrect as constipation is more commonly associated with colonic function disruptions or changes in diet following gastrointestinal surgery, not specifically related to the ileum or jejunum resections which would more likely impact diarrhea due to reduced absorption capacities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The resection of the terminal ileum specifically compromises vitamin B12 absorption due to the loss of the primary site where the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex is absorbed. This can lead to significant clinical issues related to vitamin B12 deficiency, such as anemia and neurological disturbances, unless managed with appropriate supplementation.

 

Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors

 

  • Iron is absorbed in duodenum and upper jejunum
  • Folate is absorbed in jejunum
  • Vitamin B12 is absorbed in terminal Ileum

questions.text: A few hours following forceps delivery, patient complained of pain in perineum. On examination, she had hypotension, tachycardia and the episiotomy site had a large bluish swelling. Which of the following should not be done? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Repair in ward

 

The clinical scenario describes a vulval hematoma, which is a serious postpartum complication. The patient presents with classical symptoms:

 

  • Pain in perineum
  • Hypotension and tachycardia indicating shock
  • Large bluish swelling at episiotomy site. This condition requires immediate intervention, but attempting repair in the ward would be dangerous and inappropriate. The patient requires proper surgical management in controlled conditions.
  • A repair in the ward is hence completely un-indicated in her. Drainage of the hematoma and obliteration of dead space has to be done in the OT with proper lighting and assistance and at the same time shock needs to be managed by resuscitation with fluids and blood

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blood transfusion: Correct step. The patient is in shock with hypotension and tachycardia, indicating significant blood loss into the hematoma. Blood transfusion is essential for resuscitation.

 

Option C. Inform senior: Correct step. Given the severity of the condition and need for surgical intervention, senior consultation is necessary.

 

Option D. Shift to OT: Correct step. The patient requires evacuation of hematoma and obliteration of dead space under proper anesthesia, which can only be done in an operation theater.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A vulval hematoma presenting after delivery requires immediate resuscitation and surgical evacuation in the operation theater, never repair in the ward, due to:

 

  • Need for proper anesthesia
  • Potential for significant blood loss
  • Presence of dead space requiring proper surgical obliteration
  • Risk of shock

questions.text: FAD status in body is determined by?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glutathione reductase

 

This is the correct answer. Glutathione reductase is an enzyme that contains FAD as a prosthetic group and plays a significant role in the reduction of glutathione disulfide (GSSG) to glutathione (GSH). The activity of glutathione reductase, which depends on the availability of FAD, can be used to assess tissue riboflavin (FAD precursor) status. Therefore, measuring the activity of glutathione reductase with and without FAD is a method for assessing FAD status in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine, also known as Vitamin B1, is not directly involved in determining FAD status. Thiamine plays a crucial role in carbohydrate metabolism but doesn't directly influence the levels of FAD in the body.

 

Option C. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is an enzyme involved in the first step of glucose metabolism, but it is not responsible for determining FAD status.

 

Option D. Transketolase: Transketolase is marker enzyme for B1 deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FAD is the active form of Vitamin B2 and marker for the B2 deficiency is RBC glutathione reductase activity as this enzyme require B2 as coenzyme. So, in case of FAD deficiency, glutathione reductase activity will be lowered without affecting the quantity of enzyme.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 534

questions.text: A female patient who is from the north-eastern part of the country came to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling of the upper limb. She has a history of coronary artery disease for which she underwent percutaneous coronary intervention. On examination, the limbs are more swollen proximally than distally. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Night blood test for worms

 

The clinical presentation described suggests lymphatic filariasis, a parasitic disease caused by filarial worms. Lymphatic filariasis commonly leads to lymphedema, especially of the extremities, due to obstruction of lymphatic vessels by the parasites. The characteristic finding of limb swelling that is more pronounced proximally than distally is typical for lymphatic involvement.

 

Night Blood Test for Worms: This is the appropriate diagnostic test as filarial worms are nocturnally periodic, meaning that the microfilariae (larval stage of the filarial worm) are present in peripheral blood predominantly during the night (between 10 pm and 4 am). This periodicity aligns with the feeding patterns of the mosquito vectors that transmit the parasite.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Echocardiography: This would typically be used to assess heart function and structure, especially relevant given her history of coronary artery disease, but it would not be useful for diagnosing conditions affecting the lymphatic system like filariasis.

 

Option C. Duplex venous scan of limbs: This test assesses venous circulation and could help rule out venous thrombosis or other venous insufficiencies but would not be the first choice when filariasis is suspected.

 

Option D. ECG: While important for monitoring heart conditions, an ECG would not provide information relevant to diagnosing or managing lymphatic swelling due to filariasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In regions endemic for filariasis, such as parts of northeastern India, the presentation of unexplained lymphedema warrants a night blood test for worms to check for the presence of microfilariae. Early diagnosis and treatment can prevent the progression of lymphatic damage and reduce the severity of lymphedema.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child came with complaints of fast breathing of RR 48 per minute with no chest in drawing. What is your diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pneumonia

 

According to the IMNCI (Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness) guidelines, respiratory rate (RR) cutoffs for diagnosing pneumonia in children are as follows:

 

  • Age 0–2 months → RR > 60/min → Fast breathing
  • Age 2 months – 1 year → RR > 50/min → Fast breathing
  • Age 1–5 years → RR > 40/min → Fast breathing

 

The child in the question is 2 years old with a RR of 48/min, which is above the cutoff of 40/min for pneumonia, but there is no chest indrawing or danger signs. This is classified as "pneumonia" according to IMNCI​

 

Classification Based on IMNCI Guidelines:

 

  • No pneumonia (A): Normal breathing rate, no signs of distress.
  • Pneumonia (B) (This Case): Fast breathing (tachypnea) but no chest indrawing or danger signs.
  • Severe pneumonia (C): Fast breathing + chest indrawing or danger signs (e.g., inability to feed, convulsions, lethargy, cyanosis).
  • Very severe pneumonia (D): Not a recognized IMNCI category (IMNCI only classifies pneumonia as "pneumonia" or "severe pneumonia").

 

Educational Objective:

 

A respiratory rate of 48/min in a 2-year-old without chest indrawing is classified as pneumonia. IMNCI guidelines recommend oral amoxicillin for five days as the first-line treatment for non-severe pneumonia.

questions.text: A pure tone audiometry (PTA) result shows an air-bone gap with normal bone conduction thresholds. What is the most likely type of hearing loss? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conductive hearing loss (CHL)

 

Explanation: 


The PTA findings indicate conductive hearing loss because:

 

  • Bone conduction is normal (within 25 dB threshold).
  • Air conduction is affected (elevated threshold).
  • There is a gap between air and bone conduction curves.
  • This pattern indicates that sound transmission through the external/middle ear is impaired while inner ear function is normal.
  • The presence of air-bone gap with normal bone conduction is pathognomonic of conductive hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)

 

  • Both air and bone conduction would be affected
  • No significant air-bone gap
  • Curves would be close to each other in affected range

 

Option C. Mixed hearing loss

 

  • Both air and bone conduction would be affected
  • Air-bone gap present but bone conduction also abnormal
  • Both curves would be in affected range with a gap between them

 

Option D. Normal hearing

 

  • Both air and bone conduction would be within normal range (≤25 dB)
  • No air-bone gap
  • Both curves would be close together in normal range

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Air-bone gap with normal bone conduction thresholds on pure tone audiometry is diagnostic of conductive hearing loss.

questions.text: In a 10-year-old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the school immunization program? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) TT/Td vaccine

 

In the national immunization schedule, the TT/Td vaccine is given to children at 10 years & 16 years of age as part of the school immunization program.

 

Additional Information

 

Age Limits for Delayed Immunization in NIS, India

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measles Vaccine can be given till 5 years of age.

 

Option B. Rotavirus vaccines can be given till 12 years of age.

 

Option D. Hepatitis B vaccine can be given till 1 year of age.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

National Immunisation schedule (2023-24):

choices.text: Testing all the dogs for rabies
Reduce stray dog population and vaccinate all dogs
Increase capacity of healthcare workers for surveillance

questions.text: While numerous animals play a role in the transmission of rabies, dogs stand out as the most common ones. Moreover, the impact of this disease is often more in children. Given this understanding, what approach would be both economically efficient and rational to reduce the occurrence of rabies? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Reduce stray dog population and vaccinate all dogs

 

Since dogs are the primary source of infection, the most cost-effective (and logical) strategy would be Elimination of stray dogs and taking a step towards mass immunization. This approach directly addresses the primary source of infection and helps break the transmission cycle of the rabies virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Testing all the dogs for rabies: Not economically efficient due to the large number of dogs and the high cost of testing. It also does not prevent the spread of the disease.

 

Option C. Strengthening laboratory facilities: While important for diagnosis and monitoring, this does not address the primary prevention of rabies through vaccination and control of the dog population.

 

Option D. Increase capacity of healthcare workers for surveillance: Surveillance is crucial but does not directly prevent rabies transmission. It is more of a reactive approach rather than a proactive prevention strategy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reducing the stray dog population and vaccinating all dogs is the most economically efficient and rational approach to reduce the occurrence of rabies. This strategy directly targets the primary source of infection and helps prevent the spread of the disease.

questions.text: A known patient of tuberculosis, on INH for the past 3 months complains of numbness, tingling and burning sensation in all the extremities. What could be vitamin deficiency?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6

 

This is the correct answer. Isoniazid (INH) can lead to a deficiency in Vitamin B6. Peripheral neuropathy, which includes symptoms like numbness, tingling, and burning sensations in the extremities, is a common side effect of Vitamin B6 deficiency. Therefore, the patient's symptoms are likely a result of this deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin) Deficiency: Vitamin B12 deficiency can also cause neuropathy and neurological symptoms, but it's less likely to be associated with INH use specifically. However, it's essential to consider Vitamin B12 levels in tuberculosis patients, as they may have dietary restrictions or other factors that could lead to this deficiency.

 

Option C. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) Deficiency: Vitamin B1 deficiency can cause a condition called beriberi, which can include neurological symptoms. However, INH is not known to directly cause Vitamin B1 deficiency.

 

Option D. Vitamin B3 (Niacin) Deficiency: Niacin deficiency can lead to a condition called pellagra, which includes skin issues and neurological symptoms. INH can indirectly affect niacin levels, but it's not a common cause of niacin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Isoniazid inhibits pyridoxal phosphokinase which is required for synthesis of biologically active form of pyridoxine (B6) i.e. pyridoxal phosphate. Thus, isoniazid inhibits the formation of the active form of B6.
  • As Vit. B6 (PLP) is required for niacin (B3) synthesis from tryptophan, hence isoniazid therapy also causes Niacin deficiency.
  • In this question, best answer to mark is B6 as INH directly inhibits B6 formation.

 

Reference: Dinesh Puri 3rd ed/pg-371

choices.text: LH from maternal pituitary
HCG from placenta
Inhibin from corpus luteum
GnRH from fetal hypothalamus

questions.text: Testosterone helps in the development of various organs in the fetus. Which of the following stimulates its production? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HCG from placenta

 

Explanation:

 

  • HCG from placenta:
    • HCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) from the placenta stimulates the production of testosterone in the male fetus.
    • HCG released from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus.
    • Later by the eighth week of gestation, fetal pituitary LH (luteinizing hormone) stimulates the Leydig cells of the testes to produce testosterone.
    • Sex differentiation of the embryo depends on the Y chromosome, which contains the testis-determining gene called the SRY (sex-determining region on Y) gene.
    • In a genetically male embryo (46, XY), the gonad is converted into testis under the influence of this gene.
    • Female development (Mullerian ducts) occurs in the absence of this gene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LH from maternal pituitary: Maternal LH does not play a role in fetal testosterone production. The fetal pituitary gland, not the maternal pituitary, influences testosterone production later in gestation.

 

Option C. Inhibin from corpus luteum: Inhibin is involved in the regulation of FSH and does not stimulate testosterone production. It primarily acts to provide feedback inhibition to the anterior pituitary gland to control FSH levels.

 

Option D. GnRH from fetal hypothalamus: GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone) from the fetal hypothalamus plays a role in stimulating the fetal pituitary to release LH and FSH, but it is not the initial trigger for testosterone production in the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HCG from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus.

 

Ref: Page 103, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Truck driver presents with painful genital ulcers as shown in the picture. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chancroid

 

Chancroid, caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi, presents as painful genital ulcers. The ulcers are typically soft, with irregular borders and a base that may be covered with a gray or yellowish material. The presence of multiple, painful ulcers with some slough and pus is characteristic of chancroid. It is important to differentiate chancroid from other sexually transmitted infections that present with genital ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chancre: A chancre is the primary lesion of syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum. It is typically a solitary, painless ulcer with a clean base and indurated margins. This does not match the description or appearance of the ulcers in this case.

 

Option C. Donovanosis: Also known as granuloma inguinale, this condition is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It presents with painless, beefy-red granulomatous ulcers that tend to bleed easily. The ulcers in the image are not consistent with this description.

 

Option D. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV): LGV is caused by certain serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis. It typically presents with painless genital ulcers followed by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes). The ulcers themselves are not painful, which differentiates it from chancroid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chancroid is characterized by painful genital ulcers with irregular borders and a base that may be covered with slough or pus, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

choices.text: Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery
Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, a habitual smoker, visits the hospital. He describes experiencing recurring pain in his thighs and buttocks when he walks, particularly noticeable after covering a distance of approximately 500 meters. What could be a plausible diagnosis for his symptoms?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arterial disease with intermittent claudication due to aortoiliac occlusion. Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs, particularly during walking, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease, also known as Leriche syndrome in more severe cases if associated with impotence.
  • The aortoiliac arteries are major blood vessels that supply the lower half of the body. Blockages in these arteries can lead to pain in the buttocks, thighs, or hips upon exertion. The claudication pain in the buttocks or thighs, as described by the patient, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease. Therefore, this is the most plausible diagnosis given the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery: This type of arterial disease would involve blockage in the superficial femoral artery, which runs through the thigh. Patients with this condition typically experience claudication pain in the calf muscles because the superficial femoral artery primarily supplies the calf muscles.

 

Option C. Femoral venous insufficiency: Femoral venous insufficiency involves issues with the veins, not the arteries. This condition typically leads to symptoms like leg swelling, varicose veins, and skin changes, but it does not cause claudication or pain upon walking specific distances.

 

Option D. Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery: The profunda femoris artery is a deep artery of the thigh. Blockage in this artery can cause pain, but the pain would typically present differently from the described scenario. The location and type of pain would be more localized to the thigh rather than involving the buttocks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs during walking, particularly in a habitual smoker, is highly suggestive of arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement. This is characterized by blockages in the aortoiliac arteries, leading to decreased blood flow to the lower extremities.

questions.text: Pneumoconiosis associated with exposure to cotton dust is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Byssinosis.

 

Byssinosis, also known as "brown lung disease," is a type of pneumoconiosis specifically associated with exposure to cotton dust. It is an occupational lung disease that typically affects workers in the textile industry, including those involved in spinning, weaving, and processing cotton. The inhalation of cotton dust can cause the airways to become constricted, leading to symptoms such as chest tightness, coughing, and wheezing, particularly at the start of the workweek, which is sometimes referred to as "Monday fever."

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bagassosis: This is a pneumoconiosis caused by exposure to bagasse, the fibrous material left over after sugarcane or sorghum stalks are crushed to extract their juice. It is commonly seen in workers in the sugar industry.

 

Option C. Anthracosis: Also known as "black lung disease," this condition is caused by the inhalation of coal dust. It primarily affects coal miners and results in the accumulation of carbon particles in the lungs.

 

Option D. Silicosis: Silicosis is caused by the inhalation of silica dust, which is commonly found in industries like cement, glass manufacturing, and stone cutting. It leads to inflammation and scarring in the lungs.

 

Note –

 

Asbestosis: Caused by exposure to asbestos dust, asbestosis is a serious condition that leads to lung fibrosis. It is prevalent among workers in the cement industry and is particularly noted in shipyard workers due to the historical use of asbestos in ship construction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

List of Pneumoconiosis:

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Rivaroxaban? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Factor X inhibitor

 

Rivaroxaban is an oral anticoagulant that functions as a direct Factor Xa inhibitor. Factor Xa plays a crucial role in the coagulation cascade, leading to the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin, which subsequently forms fibrin clots. By inhibiting Factor Xa, Rivaroxaban effectively prevents the formation of thrombin and subsequent clot formation, providing anticoagulant effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Direct Thrombin inhibitor: Drugs that act as direct thrombin inhibitors include Dabigatran, Argatroban, Bivalirudin, and Lepirudin. These drugs directly inhibit thrombin, preventing the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin.

 

Option C. Increased ATIII activity: This mechanism is associated with heparins and heparinoids. These drugs enhance the activity of antithrombin III (ATIII), which inactivates thrombin and other proteases involved in blood clotting.

 

Option D. Vitamin K inhibition: Warfarin and other coumarin derivatives inhibit the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, and X) by inhibiting vitamin K epoxide reductase. This reduces the body's ability to form clots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rivaroxaban is a direct Factor Xa inhibitor, which prevents the formation of thrombin and subsequent clot formation in the coagulation cascade.

questions.text: The given image is the logo for which of the following health programs? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) National Leprosy Eradication Program


The logo shown is for the National Leprosy Eradication Program (NLEP). The design of the logo holds significant meaning:

 

  • Sun: The sun in the center of the hand symbolizes hope and optimism, reflecting the positive outcomes of leprosy treatment.
  • Lotus Flower: This represents purity and beauty, indicating that there should be no stigma attached to those affected by leprosy.
  • Cured Thumb: The image of the healed thumb symbolizes that leprosy is a 100% curable disease. The thumb indicates that the affected person has been cured and is now a fully integrated member of society.
  • House-Shaped Hand: The hand shaped like a house emphasizes that the cured individual is an integral part of their family and community.

 

These elements collectively reinforce the message of hope, inclusion, and the need to remove stigma associated with leprosy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Integrated Disease Surveillance Program (logo):

 

 

Option B.  National TB Elimination Program (logo):

 

 

Option D.  National Health Mission (logo):

 

 

Educational Objective:


The National Leprosy Eradication Program logo symbolizes hope, the curability of leprosy, and the inclusion of cured individuals into society, promoting a stigma-free approach towards the disease.

questions.text: A child presented with dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cretinism

 

The child presents with symptoms that are highly characteristic of congenital hypothyroidism, also known as cretinism. These symptoms include dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia (enlarged tongue), and umbilical hernia. Congenital hypothyroidism is a condition that arises from insufficient thyroid hormone production at birth. If untreated, it can lead to mental retardation and developmental delays. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent long-term adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prader-Willi syndrome: This genetic disorder is characterized by hypotonia, feeding difficulties in infancy, followed by hyperphagia and obesity in childhood, intellectual disability, and characteristic facial features. It does not typically present with macroglossia or umbilical hernia.

 

Option C. Edward syndrome: Also known as Trisomy 18, Edward syndrome presents with severe intellectual disability, congenital heart defects, and distinct facial features. While it can present with a range of symptoms, dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia are not typical features.

 

Option D. Galactosemia: This metabolic disorder is due to an inability to metabolize galactose properly. Symptoms include jaundice, vomiting, poor weight gain, and lethargy. It does not typically present with macroglossia, dry skin, or rough hair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cretinism, or congenital hypothyroidism, should be considered in infants presenting with dry skin, rough hair, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent long-term developmental delays.

choices.text: Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

questions.text: A woman is planned for a laparoscopic hysterectomy. She asks the surgeon for any disadvantages of this procedure. What is the disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

 

Laparoscopic hysterectomy is a minimally invasive procedure that offers numerous benefits compared to open surgery. However, one significant disadvantage is the difficulty in assessing the extent of thermal burns. Thermal burns can occur due to the use of electrosurgical instruments, and the limited visual field in laparoscopic surgery can make it challenging to identify and evaluate the full extent of these burns. This limitation is crucial because undetected thermal injury can lead to postoperative complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prolonged recovery time: Laparoscopic surgery typically results in a shorter recovery time compared to open surgery. The minimally invasive nature of the procedure means less tissue damage and faster healing.

 

Option C. Increased bleeding: Laparoscopic surgery generally involves less blood loss than open surgery. The precision of the instruments and the smaller incisions contribute to reduced bleeding.

 

Option D. Increased pain: One of the advantages of laparoscopic surgery is less postoperative pain. The smaller incisions and less invasive approach result in decreased pain and discomfort for the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery is not knowing the extent of thermal burns.

choices.text: Reassure and review the couple after 6 months

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman accompanied by her mother-in-law comes to the infertility clinic. She has been having regular intercourse for 6 months but is not able to conceive. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reassure and review the couple after 6 months

 

Infertility is defined as the inability of a couple to conceive after 1 year of unprotected intercourse. For women under the age of 35, it is recommended to wait and try for one year before starting any investigations. Since the woman in this scenario is only 23 years old and has been trying to conceive for only 6 months, the best approach is to reassure her and advise her to continue trying. Investigations are not indicated at this stage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Semen analysis for husband: Although semen analysis is an essential part of infertility workup, it is typically not indicated until the couple has been trying to conceive for at least one year if the woman is under 35 years old.

 

Option C. Hysterolaparoscopy: This is an invasive procedure used to evaluate the female reproductive tract, typically reserved for cases where initial evaluations suggest abnormalities or for women who have been trying to conceive for a longer period.

 

Option D. Diagnostic hysteroscopy: This procedure is used to examine the inside of the uterus and is generally indicated for investigating suspected uterine abnormalities or after a longer period of unsuccessful conception attempts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For women under 35 years old, it is recommended to try to conceive for one year before starting infertility investigations.

questions.text: 18-year-old girl presents with bilateral ptosis and difficulty in chewing and combing. Her problems tend to worsen with activity. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myasthenia Gravis

 

Myasthenia Gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by weakness and fatigue of the skeletal muscles. The weakness typically worsens with activity and improves with rest, which is a hallmark of the disease. The symptoms are caused by antibodies that block or destroy nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, leading to decreased transmission of nerve impulses to the muscles.

 

In this case, the presence of bilateral ptosis (drooping of the eyelids) and difficulty in activities such as chewing and combing, which worsen with activity, are classic signs of Myasthenia Gravis. These symptoms reflect the muscle fatigue and weakness that are characteristic of the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lambert Eaton Syndrome: This condition also involves muscle weakness, but it typically improves with repeated activity. It is often associated with small cell lung cancer and involves autoantibodies against presynaptic calcium channels, leading to reduced acetylcholine release.

 

Option C. Myotonic dystrophy: This genetic disorder involves progressive muscle wasting and weakness but does not typically present with ptosis and the fluctuating weakness seen in Myasthenia Gravis. It is characterized by myotonia (difficulty relaxing muscles) rather than fatigue with activity.

 

Option D. Guillain Barre syndrome:  An acute autoimmune disorder that affects the peripheral nervous system, leading to rapid onset of muscle weakness and paralysis. It does not present with ptosis and is associated with ascending muscle weakness rather than fatigue that worsens with activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia Gravis is characterized by muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest, with ptosis and difficulty in tasks requiring sustained muscle effort being common symptoms.

questions.text: Presence of different refractive powers (+5D in one eye and +1D in the other eye) in a 10-year-old boy is suggestive of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anisometropic amblyopia

 

 

Anisometropic amblyopia is the most appropriate diagnosis in this case. It occurs when there is a significant difference in refractive error between the two eyes (typically more than 2.5 diopters). In this scenario, the difference is 4 diopters (+5D in one eye and +1D in the other), which exceeds the threshold. This difference can lead to unequal visual inputs during the critical period of visual development, resulting in amblyopia or "lazy eye" in the eye with the higher refractive error.

 

Causes of Amblyopia:

 

  1. Stimulus Deprivation Amblyopia: Typically occurs if there's a visual obstruction during developmental years, such as congenital cataract. Even after the obstruction (e.g., cataract) is surgically removed, the affected eye may not achieve normal vision due to the lack of proper visual stimuli during a critical period of visual development.
  2. Strabismic Amblyopia: Occurs when one eye deviates away (strabismus) and does not focus in alignment with the other eye, leading the deviated eye to be underused and become 'lazy.'
  3. Anisometropic Amblyopia: Arises from a significant difference in refractive errors between the two eyes, causing one eye to be less used than the other.
  4. Isoametropic (or ametropic) Amblyopia: Both eyes have high refractive errors and have not been corrected during critical developmental years, leading to underdevelopment in visual acuity in both eyes.

 

The primary treatment for amblyopia involves patching the stronger eye. This forces the amblyopic (lazy) eye to work harder, promoting visual development and function. This method is most effective during the early years, aligning with the critical period of visual development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amblyopia:  While this is partially correct, it's the second best answer. Amblyopia is a visual development disorder where an eye fails to achieve normal visual acuity, devoid of any detectable structural issues of the eye.

 

Option C. Malingering:  Incorrect. This refers to intentional feigning or exaggeration of symptoms, which is not suggested by the given clinical scenario.

 

Option D. Refractive errors:  While refractive errors are present, this answer doesn't capture the key issue of the significant difference between the eyes and its potential consequences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A difference in refractive power between the two eyes of more than 2.5 diopters can lead to anisometropic amblyopia, especially if untreated during the critical period of visual development (up to about 7 years of age)

choices.text: Improves on treatment of thyroid status
Vision loss may be seen in some cases
10% may be euthyroid at presentation

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true about the given image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Improves on treatment of thyroid status

 

Thyroid eye disease (TED), as seen in the image, is characterized by features like proptosis and upper eyelid retraction. The condition arises from an antigen-antibody interaction, specifically involving antibodies against thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptors, which mistakenly cross-react with extraocular muscle proteins. This interaction leads to inflammation, edema, and subsequent enlargement of the muscle belly, sparing the tendons.

 

The disease process is not directly related to the thyroid hormone status of the patient. Thus, managing the thyroid hormone levels does not directly improve TED. Instead, treatments like steroids and radiation therapy are used to control the inflammation and reduce edema. This is why the statement that TED improves with thyroid status treatment is incorrect.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vision loss may be seen in some cases: This statement is correct. In TED, the enlarged extraocular muscles within the confined orbital space can compress the optic nerve, leading to compressive optic neuropathy and potential vision loss.

 

Option C. 10% may be euthyroid at presentation: This is true. Even though TED is commonly associated with hyperthyroidism, about 10% of patients can present with normal thyroid hormone levels, or a euthyroid state, because the underlying issue is an immune response rather than hormone levels.

 

Option D. NOSPECS classification is used: Correct. The NOSPECS classification is widely used to grade the severity of thyroid eye disease, ranging from no signs (Class 0) to sight loss (Class 6). This classification helps in assessing and managing the disease progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroid eye disease is primarily an immune-mediated condition that does not directly improve with the management of thyroid hormone levels; its treatment focuses on controlling inflammation through immunosuppressive therapies.

questions.text: A 24-year-old presented with swelling in the wrist joint. Histopathological examination of the swelling revealed spindle cells with palisading of the nuclei and Verocay bodies. Which of the following is the most likely condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schwannoma

 

The histopathological examination is suggestive of schwannoma.

 

Schwannomas are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that surround but do not invade the associated nerve. They are frequently associated with NF2 gene inactivating mutations on chromosome 22g12.

 

The tumor is composed of fibrocellular bundles that form a whorled pattern under the microscope. There are dense and compact cellular areas (Antoni A pattern) that alternate with loose acellular areas (Antoni B pattern). Antoni A pattern areas have palisaded nuclei known as Verocay bodies. Nerve fibres are typically found stretched across the capsule but not within the tumor. Hemosiderin and lipid-laden macrophages are found in degeneration areas.

 

Schwann cells characteristically express S-100 protein.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neurofibroma: Neurofibromas are also benign nerve sheath tumors but differ histologically. They are not encapsulated and involve the nerve itself. They do not show the distinct Antoni A and B patterns or Verocay bodies seen in schwannomas.

 

Option C. Neuroma: Neuromas are non-neoplastic proliferations of nerve tissue, often occurring after nerve injury. They lack the distinctive histopathological features of spindle cells with palisading nuclei and Verocay bodies.

 

Option D. Glioma: Gliomas are primary tumors of the central nervous system originating from glial cells. They do not present with the histopathological features described and are not typically found in peripheral locations like the wrist joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schwannomas are characterized by spindle cells with palisading nuclei and Verocay bodies, forming well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses. These features, along with S-100 protein expression, distinguish schwannomas from other types of nerve sheath tumors and central nervous system tumors.

questions.text: A child with a history of night-blindness presented to you with the following findings. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Phrynoderma

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of a child with night blindness and multiple hyperkeratotic papules on the elbows, as depicted in the image, raises suspicion of a diagnosis called phrynoderma or toad-skin. This condition is often linked to a deficiency of vitamin A (VAD).
  • It is characterized by the development of keratotic follicular papules, initially appearing on the anterolateral thighs and posterolateral upper arms, and subsequently spreading to the extensor surfaces of the extremities, shoulders, abdomen, back, buttocks, face, and posterior neck.
  • While originally reported in association with vitamin A deficiency, phrynoderma is a non-specific finding that can also be observed in deficiencies of B-complex vitamins, vitamin C, vitamin E, essential fatty acids (EFA deficiency), protein-energy malnutrition (PEM), and general states of malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Keratosis pilaris:

  • Description: Keratosis pilaris is a common, benign skin condition that manifests as tiny, rough-feeling bumps on the skin, often likened to "chicken skin." It frequently occurs on the upper arms, thighs, or cheeks.
  • It usually presents during puberty. Perifollicular erythema in addition to follicular plugging
  • Favors the upper outer arms and the thighs, but lacks discrete clusters. Treatment is purely reserved for cosmetic purposes.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis:  While keratosis pilaris can appear on the upper arms close to the elbows, it's not specifically associated with night-blindness or vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option C. Darier disease:

  • Description: Darier disease is a rare, genetic skin disorder characterized by small, hard bumps on the skin, especially on the chest, back, and forehead. These may be yellowish in color and often have a foul odor.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis While Darier disease causes papules, it is not associated with night-blindness. Other features of Darier disease are also not mentioned in the question.

 

Option D. Follicular eczema:

  • Description: This is a variant of eczema (atopic dermatitis) that specifically affects the hair follicles, leading to itchy, inflamed skin.
  • Reasons it might not fit: Though follicular eczema can cause papules, the association with night-blindness is not seen. Eczema would typically be associated with itching and possibly a history of allergies or atopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical students preparing for residency, it is crucial to associate the findings of follicular hyperkeratotic papules, especially when coupled with systemic symptoms such as night-blindness, with phrynoderma, a condition related to vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Reference:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page no 63.8

questions.text: A 22y female is overdue by 2 weeks. She visits the OPD with complaints of vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain on the right side. On Examination, her vitals are stable. Abdomen examination is unremarkable. A bimanual examination reveals a bulky, soft uterus with no tenderness and no adnexal mass. Mild bleeding +. Beta hCG is 1400 IU. An ultrasound reveals a trilaminar endometrium, and both the adnexa are normal. The next best step is?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Repeat serum beta HCG after 48h

 

Explanation:

 

  • Repeat serum beta hCG after 48h:
    • The clinical scenario suggests a pregnancy of unknown location (PUL), which could either be a failing intrauterine pregnancy or an ectopic pregnancy.
    • The best next step is to repeat the serum beta hCG level after 48 hours. A rise in beta hCG by at least 66% would suggest a viable intrauterine pregnancy, while a plateau or drop would indicate a non-viable pregnancy, such as an ectopic pregnancy or a failing intrauterine pregnancy.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Diagnostic laparoscopy: Diagnostic laparoscopy is an invasive procedure and is not the immediate next step in the management of a stable patient with PUL. It is reserved for cases where there is a high suspicion of ectopic pregnancy with unstable vital signs or inconclusive non-invasive tests.

 

Option C. Repeat USG after 3 days: Repeating the ultrasound after 3 days may not provide additional useful information if the initial ultrasound did not show an intrauterine pregnancy. Monitoring beta hCG levels first is more informative and guides the need for further imaging.

 

Option D. Wait and watch: Simply waiting without further evaluation could delay diagnosis and appropriate management, especially in the case of a potential ectopic pregnancy, which can be life-threatening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of pregnancy of unknown location (PUL), the next best step is to repeat the serum beta hCG level after 48 hours to differentiate between a viable intrauterine pregnancy and a non-viable pregnancy, such as an ectopic pregnancy or a failing intrauterine pregnancy.

 

 

Ref: page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126

questions.text: A patient presents with the skin lesion shown below. What can be used for treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nicotinamide

 

The image depicts a patient with a "Casal's necklace" rash, a characteristic sign of pellagra, a condition caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency.

 

Pellagra is referred to as the "4D disease": Dermatitis, Diarrhea, Dementia, and Death. The treatment of choice for pellagra is nicotinamide, also known as vitamin B3 or niacin, which addresses the niacin deficiency underlying the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): While important for various bodily functions, it's not the specific treatment for pellagra.

 

Option C. Vitamin A: Primarily involved in vision and immune function, not relevant to pellagra.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Crucial for wound healing and immune response, but doesn't address niacin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Casal's necklace, a dermatological manifestation with a symmetrical rash resembling a necklace around the neck, is a hallmark sign of pellagra, a condition resulting from niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency. The primary treatment for pellagra involves niacin supplementation.

questions.text: During psychotherapy, the therapist had mixed conscious and unconscious feelings towards his patient. This is known as? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Countertransference

 

Countertransference refers to the therapist's emotional reactions, both conscious and unconscious, towards a patient, often influenced by the therapist's own past.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transference: Transference is when the patient unconsciously redirects feelings experienced in an earlier relationship to the therapist.

 

Option C. Dissociation: Dissociation is a disconnection and lack of continuity between thoughts, memories, surroundings, actions, and identity.

 

Option D. Dissociation: Preoccupation is being absorbed in thought, typically about something particular.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Transference refers to the redirection of a patient's feelings and attitudes from past experiences or individuals onto the therapist, typically operating on an unconscious level. Countertransference represents the therapist's emotional reactions to a patient, both conscious and unconscious. These reactions may be influenced by the therapist's own personal history, unresolved conflicts, or reactions to the patient's transference.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 1069

questions.text: Which vaccine is typically stored in the lowest compartment of the ILR? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) OPV

 

In an Ice-Lined Refrigerator (ILR), vaccines are stored at specific temperatures to maintain their potency. The lowest compartment of the ILR is the coldest part, which is optimal for storing vaccines that require the coldest temperatures. Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) is stored in the lowest compartment because it requires the coldest storage conditions to remain effective.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penta: Pentavalent vaccine (which protects against five diseases: diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus, hepatitis B, and Haemophilus influenzae type b) does not require the lowest temperature and is generally stored in the middle compartments.

 

Option B. DPT: The DPT vaccine (Diphtheria, Pertussis, and Tetanus) does not need to be stored in the coldest compartment and is kept in the upper or middle compartments of the ILR.

 

Option C. Hep B: The Hepatitis B vaccine also does not require the lowest storage temperature and is kept in the middle compartments of the ILR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) should be stored in the lowest compartment of the Ice-Lined Refrigerator (ILR) due to its requirement for the coldest storage conditions.

questions.text: A patient with schizophrenia was on olanzapine therapy for a few months. It was effective in controlling the symptoms, but the patient stopped taking this drug. What can be the most likely reason? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Weight gain

 

Explanation:

 

  • Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic drug used in the treatment of schizophrenia. While it is effective in controlling both positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia, it is associated with several adverse effects. 
  • The most common reason patients discontinue olanzapine therapy is weight gain. 
  • Olanzapine, along with clozapine, has the highest risk of causing metabolic side effects collectively known as lipodystrophy syndrome. This syndrome includes hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, insulin resistance, and significant weight gain. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tardive dyskinesia: This is incorrect. Because tardive dyskinesia is more commonly associated with typical (first-generation) antipsychotic drugs like haloperidol rather than atypical antipsychotics like olanzapine. Atypical antipsychotics have a lower risk of causing extrapyramidal symptoms including tardive dyskinesia.

 

Option C. Agranulocytosis: This is incorrect. Because agranulocytosis is a characteristic adverse effect of clozapine, not olanzapine. Clozapine requires regular monitoring of white blood cell counts due to this potentially fatal side effect.

 

Option D. Muscular dystonia: This is incorrect. Because muscular dystonia is an extrapyramidal symptom more commonly associated with typical antipsychotic drugs. Atypical antipsychotics like olanzapine have a much lower risk of causing extrapyramidal symptoms compared to typical antipsychotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Side effects of Atypical anti- Psychotics:

 

Side effects

 

  • Cause lipodystrophy syndrome characterized by
    • ↑Glucose
    • ↑Lipids
    • Weight gain
    • Insulin Resistance
  • Risk is highest with clozapine and olanzapine

questions.text: Most common cancer in India in females is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Breast

 

In India, breast cancer is the most common cancer among females. It has surpassed cervical cancer, which previously held the top position. Breast cancer has a high incidence due to various factors, including genetic predisposition, lifestyle changes, and increased awareness leading to higher detection rates. Early detection through screening programs, such as mammography, plays a crucial role in managing and reducing the mortality associated with breast cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cervix: Cervical cancer is the second most common cancer among women in India. It is caused primarily by persistent infection with high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) types. Despite its high incidence, it is not as common as breast cancer.

 

Option C. Ovary: Ovarian cancer is less common compared to breast and cervical cancers. It often presents at a later stage due to nonspecific symptoms, making it a significant cause of gynecologic cancer mortality.

 

Option D. Endometrium: Endometrial cancer is also less common than breast and cervical cancers in India. It typically occurs in postmenopausal women and is often associated with hormonal imbalances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breast cancer is the most common cancer among females in India, highlighting the importance of regular screening and early detection to improve outcomes.

questions.text: Identify this instrument used in the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Piper forceps

 

Piper forceps are specifically designed for the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech presentations. Their unique shape allows them to grasp the head of the baby gently and guide it through the birth canal without applying excessive pressure. The long, curved shanks of Piper forceps are particularly adapted for use when the baby is in breech position, making them the most appropriate tool for this scenario.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wrigley forceps: These are outlet forceps used when the fetal head is at +3 station, fully or nearly fully rotated. They are not designed for use in breech presentations.

 

 

Option C. Kielland forceps: These are rotational forceps used when the fetal head is high and unrotated. They are meant for complex cases where rotation of the head is necessary, not for the aftercoming head in breech.

 

 

Option D. Dass forceps: These are low forceps used when the fetal head is at +2 station. They are not suitable for the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech as they are not designed for such specific maneuvering.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Piper forceps are the instrument of choice for the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech presentations due to their specialized design that facilitates safe extraction.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for splenectomy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone marrow failure

 

Bone marrow failure is not an indication for splenectomy because removing the spleen does not address the underlying cause of bone marrow failure. Splenectomy would not provide any benefit in managing or treating bone marrow failure, as the problem lies within the bone marrow's ability to produce blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iatrogenic splenic rupture: This refers to a rupture of the spleen caused inadvertently by medical intervention. In cases of splenic rupture, splenectomy is often necessary to prevent further complications such as internal bleeding.

 

Option B. Thrombocytopenia: Splenectomy can be indicated for thrombocytopenia, particularly if it is caused by conditions like Immune Thrombocytopenia (ITP), where the spleen destroys platelets.

 

Option C. Splenic infarct with sepsis: In cases where a splenic infarct leads to sepsis, splenectomy may be necessary to remove the infected spleen and control the spread of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bone marrow failure is not an indication for splenectomy, as the procedure does not address the underlying pathology of bone marrow production issues.

questions.text: The image of a drug is given below. It is used in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subglottic stenosis

 

The given drug is Mitomycin-C. It is used topically in the management of subglottic stenosis.

 

Mitomycin is an antibiotic that is isolated from the broth of Streptomyces caespitosus. This drug has demonstrated antitumor activity. Mitomycin belongs to a group of alkylating agents that work by cross-linking the complementary strands found in DNA. It also has antifibrotic property which prevents tissue scarring.

 

Thus, it can used to inhibit post-surgical scar formation and as a chemotherapeutic agent.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Rhinocerebral mucormycosis - This fungal infection requires antifungal medications, not typically treated with Mitomycin-C.

 

Option C. Adenoidectomy - A surgical procedure to remove adenoids; does not involve the use of Mitomycin-C.

 

Option D. Tympanoplasty - Surgical repair of the eardrum, where Mitomycin-C is not routinely used.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Mitomycin-C is particularly effective in preventing the recurrence of subglottic stenosis after surgery due to its antifibrotic properties, making it a critical adjunct in surgical procedures involving the airway.

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, volume 3, Page No. 1088
