questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair of substances with their renal clearance from the graph given below? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D – PAH

 

The correctly matched pair of substances and their renal clearance is option B.

 

 

The concentration of the substance changes as it passes through the tubules. Removing the substance from the filtrate is k/a tubular reabsorption and adding more of the substance to the filtrate is k/a tubular secretion.

 

Amount of the substance finally excreted = Amount Filtered + Secreted - Reabsorbed

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the renal handling of different substances such as PAH, inulin, bicarbonate, and glucose is crucial for assessing kidney function and diagnosing various renal disorders. Each substance's behavior in the nephron informs clinicians about different aspects of renal physiology, such as filtration rate and tubular function.

questions.text: Which hormone is involved in the given scenario shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oxytocin

 

Explanation: 

 

The image shows breastfeeding, which involves the milk ejection/letdown reflex mediated by oxytocin. This is a positive feedback mechanism where suckling stimulates the release of oxytocin. milk letdown reflex is one of the classic examples of positive feedback mechanisms in the body (along with other "HCLAMP" mechanisms - Hodgkin's cycle, Clotting cascade, LH surge, Activation of digestive enzymes, Milk letdown, and Parturition reflex).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adrenaline: Incorrect because adrenaline is a stress hormone released from adrenal medulla. It has no direct role in milk ejection/breastfeeding.

 

Option C. Cortisol: Incorrect because cortisol is a glucocorticoid involved in stress response and metabolism. While it may be present during breastfeeding, it is not the primary hormone responsible for milk ejection.

 

Option D. Thyroxin: Incorrect because thyroxine is involved in metabolism and growth. While it plays a supportive role in lactation by maintaining metabolic rate, it is not directly responsible for milk ejection during breastfeeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxytocin is the key hormone responsible for milk ejection/letdown reflex during breastfeeding through a positive feedback mechanism.

The participants in the study were split into five groups and the following table is formed based on the study results. Among the provided options, which statement accurately reflects the connection between CRP levels and the risk of myocardial infarction/stroke? [NEET PG 2021]

Among the given options, the best answer will be option B.

Increased CRP levels are positively associated with an increased risk of myocardial infarction (MI) and stroke. As CRP levels rise, the relative risk of these conditions also increases.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD as a known case of cervical cancer. On further evaluation, the pelvic side wall was found to be involved, and hydronephrosis was also seen. Identify the stage of cervical cancer. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3B

 

Stage 3B cervical cancer is characterized by the involvement of the pelvic side wall and the presence of hydronephrosis or non-functioning kidney due to ureteric obstruction. In this stage, the cancer has extended to the lateral pelvic wall, and often the tumor affects the ureter, leading to obstructive uropathy. This progression indicates a significant local spread of the disease, distinguishing it from earlier stages where cancer is confined closer to the cervix or upper parts of the vagina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2B: Stage 2B cervical cancer involves the spread of cancer into the parametrium but does not reach the lateral pelvic wall. It does not involve hydronephrosis or ureteric obstruction, which are key features distinguishing Stage 3B.

 

Option B. 3A: Stage 3A involves the spread of cancer to the lower third of the vagina without extension to the pelvic wall or causing hydronephrosis. It does not involve the pelvic side wall or ureteric complications, unlike Stage 3B.

 

Option D. 3C: Stage 3C is characterized by the spread of cancer to pelvic or para-aortic lymph nodes but does not necessarily involve the pelvic side wall or hydronephrosis. Stage 3C is further divided into 3C1 (pelvic lymph nodes) and 3C2 (para-aortic lymph nodes), differing from the pelvic side wall involvement seen in Stage 3B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stages of cervical cancer:

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant was brought by his mother with complaints of inability to open the eyes in light and excessive watering. The clinical picture is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Congenital glaucoma

 

  • The clinical history of inability to open eyes in light (photophobia), excessive watering, and hazy cornea suggests congenital glaucoma.
  • Primary congenital glaucoma is abnormally high intraocular pressure due to a developmental anomaly of the anterior chamber angle.
  • Classification:
    1. True congenital glaucoma: IOP raised at birth.
    2. Infantile glaucoma: Disease manifests before 3 years of age.
    3. Juvenile glaucoma: IOP rises between 3-16 years of age.
  • CYP1B1 gene is implicated in the pathogenesis.
     

 

  • Other features:
    • Corneal haze due to diffuse edema from elevated IOP
    • Buphthalmos from stretching before the age of 3 years
    • Haab striae and corneal scarring can occur.

 

  • Evaluation:
    • IOP measurement
    • Corneal diameter measurement
    • Gonioscopy
    • Ophthalmoscopy

 

  • Management 
    • Surgical with goniotomy or trabeculotomy
    • If unsuccessful: trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures are performed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In ophthalmia neonatorum, there will be inflammation of the conjunctiva. Clinical presentation includes conjunctival discharge, hyperaemia, chemosis, swollen eyelids, tender eyeball.

 

 

Option C. In mucopolysaccharidosis, there will be bilateral cloudy cornea.

 

 

Option D. In cataract, there will be opacification of lens presenting as whitish reflex/ leukocoria.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A young male patient was given regional block with 0.25% bupivacaine for a minor surgical procedure. Shortly after the injection, the patient suddenly became unresponsive and the pulse was not recordable. Which of the following would be the best course of management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CPR with 20% intralipid

 

  • The scenario described involves a young male patient who received a regional block with 0.25% bupivacaine for a minor surgical procedure and subsequently became unresponsive with an unrecordable pulse.
  •  These are concerning signs of Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST), which can occur when local anesthetic drugs like bupivacaine enter the systemic circulation.
  • The best course of management for this patient is as follows:
  • This is the correct choice. Intralipid is a lipid emulsion used as the antidote for LAST.
  • It works by sequestering the local anesthetic drug in the lipid phase and reducing its toxic effects on the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.
  •  CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation) should be initiated, and 20% intralipid should be administered intravenously to treat LAST.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CPR with sodium bicarbonate: Sodium bicarbonate is not the first-line treatment for LAST. While it can be used to treat certain cardiac arrhythmias caused by local anesthetic toxicity, it does not directly counteract the toxic effects on the central nervous system and is not as effective as intralipid.

 

Option C. CPR with dobutamine: Dobutamine is a medication used to increase cardiac output and blood pressure in some situations, but it is not the primary treatment for LAST.

 

Option D. CPR with calcium: Calcium does not reverse the toxic effects of local anesthetic systemic toxicity. Therefore, it is not the appropriate treatment for this situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient experiences LAST with signs of cardiovascular collapse and central nervous system toxicity, the recommended treatment is CPR (if necessary) along with the administration of 20% intralipid intravenously, as it helps to reverse the toxic effects of the local anesthetic and improve the patient's condition.
  • Drug of choice for treatment of LAST – 20% Intralipid IV
